Review text: We ordered this induction cooktop because we live in an area that is not supplied with natural gas, and our JennAir built-in electric non-induction stovetop seemed to take forever to simply boil a pot of water.  A friend had demonstrated their built-in induction cooktop to us; we had been impressed with a pot of water coming to boil in about two minutes, and the fact that immediately after a burner was turned off, a person could place their hand on the burner itself and and it was not hot.  So, based on the positive reviews we had read on the Amazon site, we ordered the 9100MC., We received our Duxtop countertop cooktop yesterday and, having read the instruction manual thoroughly, decided to test it by boiling 6 cups of cool water in a stainless steel pot that we had also tested would hold a magnet per the instruction manual. SEVENTEEN minutes later the water began to boil.  We were also surprised that right on the unit it said the surface would remain hot.  It did remain hot, for an additional TEN minutes., We then conducted a test for bringing water to a full boil between 1) a Russell Hobbs 1500 Watt electric tea kettle, 2) a different Le Creuset pot on the induction cooktop, and 3) a stainless pot on the JennAir stovetop. Each contained the identical amount of equallly cold water (6 cups)., The results were:, First place: the Russell Hobbs tea kettle at 6 minutes., Second place: the induction cooktop and Le Creuset pot at 10 minutes., The JennAir stovetop at 19 minutes., To our surprise, the surface of the Duxtop remained hot for an additional 17 minutes.  We also noticed that it was quite noisy (fan and other noise) when running., "This Duxtop unit did not come anywhere near what we had expected, based on reviews.  But, since nobody else seems to have complained about how long it takes the Duxtop to boil water, we have to assume that we must have received a defective device.  We are willing to give Duxtop another chance, and have used Amazons easy return service to try another unit.  Well see how the next one works, and then write another review.", It hardly seems worth the cost of this 1800 watt induction unit to save only 9 minutes of time over the JennAir.  And for it to be occupying space on a countertop and remaining hot is a problem.  It also has a footprint three times the size of our tea kettle., Since we have a kettle that is out performing the induction cooktop, we returned the unit.  Granted we do not cook food in our tea kettle, but so much of what we do (canning, blanching, cooking pasta or rice) is about bringing water to a boil.  We can simply heat the water in our kettle and put in a pot on the JennAir to remain boiling., Update November 2:  We just got our replacement Duxtop from Amazon yesterday.  It is definitely superior to the original one we got.  We conducted the same test - boiling six cups of cold water in a LeCreuset cast iron 8 inch diameter pot.  This unit took 8 minutes to get the water to a rolling boil.  After removing the pot, its fan continued to run for 1.5 minutes, and its "Hot" message remained on for 8 to 10 minutes after removing the pot., "We had hoped to reach a boil in under 4 minutes, based on other reports we had read.  We are also surprised at how long the unit remained too hot to touch.  We will be keeping this unit, but are now aware of its shortcomings.  Its rating should probably go from one star to three stars.  We highly recommend that the unit be tested when its first received, just to make sure that its working OK.  Our first one wasnt."

Review text:
I knew all of my current cookware would not work with the cooktop, I well understood that when I purchased it.

However, about half of my cookware does work with it.

Because I am so pleased with the use of this cooktop I was motivated to order a few more essential cookware.

I’ve been using this cooktop for nearly a week now, I ordered two of them.

I have not turned on my smooth top range since they arrived.

I find that learning to regulate the temperature while cooking was easy for me.

Review text: "  After careful research and a few experiments with other folks induction cooktops (NuWave, Max Burton & Tramontina), I chose the Secura DUXTOP 9100MC and havent regretted it. While the NuWave claims to have more temperature and power settings, it seemed to me that there was more frequent power cycling at comparable temp/power levels than the 9100MC. Saying nothing bad about Max Burton and Tramontina, I eliminated them for not having as many power and temperature target settings as the 15 levels (each) available on the 9100MC.", In order to maintain temperature control, in temperature mode operation, induction cookers have to cycle on and off in order to "hover" around any target temperature. One difference between lesser & better induction cooktops is how much power (actual Watts) is being cycled for any given temperature target. 5 seconds of 1800 Watts/pulse is going to be more energy violent (to whatever is being heated) than 30 seconds of 300 Watts/pulse, even though these two pulses represent the same amount of total power., "The 9100MC uses a wider range of Watts/pulse across the range of supported temperature targets than other induction cooktops, so cooking should be gentler across the lower temperature targets. theres a table in the printed manual breaking this all out.", In power level mode, I did not notice much power cycling above power level 2.5 (=500W) per power setting, indicating that the 9100MC is providing a more even/continuous flow of power to the induction coils, at each power setting, rather than pulsing fewer fixed power flows across a range of given power settings. I did not test this with an ammeter, but rather by using an IR temperature gun, aimed inside the cookware in use, and observing how water heats at different power levels., The type and quality of induction cookware is going to make a big difference in how any induction cooktop is going to perform. Aside from the magnet test, pure steel is a relatively poor conductor of heat, such that cheap steel pans are going to experience high initial temperature overshoots, in target temperature mode, and actual ring shaped hotspots on the cooking surface side over the course of any prolonged cooking, whether by power level or target temperature., "The initial target temperature overshoots occur inside the cookware because the cooktops temperature sensor is beneath the cooktops glass surface and NOT inside the actual cookware. There is always going to be a time lag before the heat, reflecting back from the bottom of the cookware, registers with the cooktops temperature sensor. It is during that initial temp sensor time lag that temperature overshoots can happen INSIDE the cookware (sometimes momentarily exceeding 500F, depending on the pot/pan). Any induction cookware that exhibits ringed hotspots while cooking is going to be VERY PROBLEMATIC for target temperature cooking on ANY induction cooktop, not just the 9100MC.", Cast iron cookware can tend to even out the ringed hotspot effect seen with cheap pure steel cookware, but cast iron is generally on the heavy side and can present other cooking issues., What I've chosen to begin collecting for induction cooking is fully bonded, "tri-clad," 18-0 stainless steel (exterior)/full-core 3004 aluminum/18-8 stainless steel(interior) cookware. The 18-0 steel exterior is the induction layer, delivering heat directly to the aluminum core. The 3004 aluminum core rapidly distributes the heat all across the bottom and sides of the cookware, eliminating the ringed hotspot problem. The 18-8 stainless steel interior provides the non-chemically reactive cooking surface. I've really come to admire Vollrath's Tribute line of pots and pans as a result. These Vollrath post/pans have completely flat bottoms, which is also a huge plus for induction cooking. High quality, tri-clad cookware, with excellent heat distribution across the entire cook surface, is a must for accurate, target-temperature-based cooking., Even slightly warped induction cookware, no matter what its composition, is going to produce very uneven heating/cooking performance (which you may or may not want)., "Partially or non-fully bonded tri-clad cookware can vibrate, between the metal layers, at certain power/temp settings, producing a high pitched whine that may or may not annoy you during cooking. Thats because the different metal layers are vibrating against one another, as a direct consequence of the induction process, and ANY air gaps/hollows between layers can then generate audible noise, which will vary from pan to pan. Generally speaking, the higher the power level, the more vibration and the greater chance that there will be a high-pitched whine.", I will never use any external steel heat diffusers in an attempt to "adapt" non-magnetic cookware for induction cooking. First, an all-steel diffuser is guaranteed to create ringed hotspots, because steel is a poor conductor of heat, making target temp cooking very problematic. Any induction diffuser essentially turns the highly power efficient induction cooktop, back into a far less efficient, radiant heat hotplate. If I wanted to cook on a hot plate, I would've used a hot plate to begin with. Induction diffusers make no sense to me, but you can always find someone who'll sell one to you., "I also took the following dB sound measurements, 3 from the front of each appliance while running:", DUXTOP 9100MC = 46-48dB, Panasonic 1100W microwave oven = 48-55dB, Kenmore refrigerator = 40-43dB, ambient kitchen = 7-13dB (from the center of kitchen, with no motors running), So, the 9100MC is louder than the fridge, but quieter than the microwave. Subjectively, the 9100MC is not too noisy for me. but your own dB readings may vary (depending on the physical condition of your cooling fan/appliances) and everyone is entitled to their sonic preferences., I like the fact that the 9100MC gives audible and visual cues that it is energized and/or cooking. Total silence in operation would be an unwelcomed and dangerous way to go., When not in use, I completely unplug the 9100MC from AC power. When the 9100MC is in use, I make sure that no other appliances on the same circuit (not just the same plug) are ever in concurrent use, 1800W is 1800W., One thing that surprised me when using my older cookware from gas cooking days, on the 9100MC, was the amount of white, waxy build-up that would suddenly appear on the 9100MC's glass cooktop. It turns out that thin oil residue/skin, that builds up over time from radiant heat cooking, on the outside/bottom of cookware (no matter how "clean" it may look to the eye), gets literally boiled off of the cookware, by induction heating, depositing a cloudy "wax" on the cooktop's glass. In order to remove this waxy boil-off and restore the original beauty of the 9100MC cooktop, I used a fish-oil based, light machine oil, as a solvent, a microfiber cloth and the requisite elbow grease., "Even though the printed manual says not to place the 9100MC on top of any steel surface, Ive found that there are no EM/RF heating effects below the 9100MC when the unit is sitting directly on top of a steel cooking cart or on top of a steel wire rack.", The angled control panel is a big plus. There is no way for a pot/pan to damage the panel from direct "hot" contact while on the cooktop surface. I also have faith that the plastic-film covered blister-style control buttons are durable enough for my needs and actually prefer them over "touch" sensor controls. I want the tactile sense that a button has been pressed., The two things most likely to fail, IMO, are the induction coil cooling fan and the glass cooktop. While I have no intention of abusing my 9100MC, I have no idea what kind of bearing system the fan uses (ball bearings=best, sleeve bearing=worst). The printed manual also says the unit cannot support more than 25lbs total load. So, I bit the bullet and purchased a multi-year asurion/Canopy protection policy, as either of these failures would be total showstoppers., "The only modification that I made to the 9100MC is to add an air intake filter to the exterior of the case opening for the induction coil cooling fan. I did this to reduce the odds that lint/dust/oil vapor will be sucked inside the case by the fan, without impeding airflow. The filter is made from soft screen material designed for use with overhead cooking exhaust fans and is held in place by a frame of painters tape.", Induction cooking has it's own learning curve. I'm finding that power-level cooking is more useful and successful than target temperature cooking for dynamic, hands on cooking. I never start a "cold" pan in target temperature mode, in order to reduce the risk of initial temperature overshoots. I use an IR temp gun to learn how different pots/pans perform on the induction cooktop. I find the 9100MC's wider variety of power and target temp settings, in the low and medium ranges, are very useful and sufficiently granular for my cooking needs -- along with understanding how my different pots/pans actually perform., I have no need for the 9100MC to have a 212F target temp setting. I live at sea level. If I want 212F, then I cook in boiling water or with atmospheric steam and let the water/steam control 212F. Or, I will use a convection oven set to 212F. I do want very even heating/energy delivery at whatever setting I pick and the 9100MC delivers that in spades. Induction cooking, once mastered, makes it very difficult to accidentally burn food, and opens up slower/lower-temp dynamic/interactive cooking as a whole new world to explore., "As far as Lafraise is concerned, I have no complaints. I will say that Amazon shipping did not do a first class job of packaging the retail 9100MC box for shipping. The Amazon box was holed in transit and there was inadequate padding inside the Amazon box, such that the retail packaging suffered a minor puncture. My 9100MC arrived undamaged and fully functional, but Amazon needs to do a better job to protect Lafraises good reputation in the Marketplace by shipping more promptly, with better protective packaging."

After a bit of a learning curve, the Duxtop is performing well.  

The almost instant heat is a real asset.  

Clean up is remarkably easy.  

When the "HOT" warning goes off, a moist paper towel will do the trick most of the time.

We were going to replace our range top with a total induction top.  

We think now that this is not necessary.  

That means we save a lot of money.  

We can buy a second one to use and still be many dollars ahead.

Another asset is portability.

Review text:
"Good brand, had high hopes for this - its a nice size, appears well built.

However, it turned out to be quite disappointing in terms of performance.

There are only three presets and you cant change the temperature outside of that: 140° F (warm), 260° F (slow cook), and 460° F (boil & hot pot).

I found myself having to constantly go back and forth between temperatures to get the temperature I needed.

Bothersome and ultimately impractical for cooking.

Review text: I use this thing for low country boils which I prepare in a 7 gallon steel pot. I used to use a gas fired grill, but when that went My friend recommended an induction cooktop. (He has one that cost twice as much.) This is about the only stand alone stove top I would attempt to heat 7 gallons on. It works very well. Almost as fast as gas (and a lot more convenient). it heats FAR faster than regular electric plates. I understand now why chefs being forced to abandon gas are going for these induction stove tops., OF course the one caveat is that you need appropriate cook wear.

Review text:
We started using this induction cooktop because our cast iron pans don't fit well simultaneously on the stovetop.

I noticed right away how much faster it heats up.

There was steam coming from the food in less than 10 seconds, which says alot considering how long it takes my cast iron pans to heat up normally.

I usually heat up my pan well in advance of adding the food but with this cooktop you must follow the instructions and only turn it on with food already in the pan.

This item arrived quickly and in perfect condition.

I was surprised at the size - it was a little bit larger than i expected but pretty lightweight and fit nicely on the counter.

This produce works with a magnetic field or something, and so it gets hot instantly.

You need to have metal cookware.

It takes like 1 or 2 minutes to boil water.

I cooked some soup for maybe 3 minutes?

burned it completely.

( I was not watching it).

I really like it.

Review text:
Did a simple test to see if it really was that fast.

Compared to my gas stove: 2 cups water boiled in 2 min (induction) vs 4 min (gas).

Same tea kettle, same temp of starting water.  

Cooking: olive oil was heated in about 5 sec (seriously in the time it took me to replace the bottle), 1 c onions cooked in less than 1 min. Whole veggie stir fry was done in less than 5 min.  

Had it on medium so the veggies would steam.  

Really amazing!  

Considerably more efficient than my gas stove.

Review text: We have always had gas cooktops in the past, but I bought this to try because the gas cook tops make me sick and I’m not able to cook with them. I have severe MCS. This induction cooktop by mueller just plugs into any 15 amp outlet, and I love the easy preset functions. I have homi chef cookware that is nickel free 21/0 stainless steel and they work beautifully together. I was able to cook without struggling to breathe. It heated up so fast, and cooked food quickly and evenly without burning. I’m sold. If this brand makes a residential sized cooktop I’m getting it. This single burner is so lightweight and portable. It can be used in so many applications. If you’re looking to try an induction cooktop, try this one. You won’t be disappointed.

Review text:
Minor complaints:, "1) It doesnt have 10 power levels, it has 5 power levels, and the pulses the power on and off at the lowest level to effectively reduce it further.  

The problem with this is that the power output for setting L (one step below 1) through 5 are all the same, which makes burning pancakes quite easy.  

The easy work around for this is to use an induction plate between your induction cooktop and your induction pan to help even out the heating cycles.

Review text:
Side note, I wont purchase anything GE for my house ever again.

, Features are good and plentiful.  

My main issue is with the control over the heating.  

With my old cooktop, when you wanted to simmer (say low or med), it changed the intensity of the heating element, not just duration it was on.  

With this cooktop, it is full power on and off, the level L thru H, only changes how long the element is on (at full power)., Other than that, it is decent so far.

Review text: I replaced a GE induction cooktop that went bad after only 5 years.  Granted this is not a $1200 cooktop, so you cannot expect the same level of cooking control that Bosch and others can offer.  Side note, I wont purchase anything GE for my house ever again., Features are good and plentiful.  My main issue is with the control over the heating.  With my old cooktop, when you wanted to simmer (say low or med), it changed the intensity of the heating element, not just duration it was on.  With this cooktop, it is full power on and off, the level L thru H, only changes how long the element is on (at full power)., Other than that, it is decent so far.  Will update as needed based on more use.

Review text: This was our first induction stove top so we had no prior experience. Having read the reviews, this seemed like the best buy. After having had it for a month, I can report that this unit is spectacular. First, the installation was easily and quickly accomplished. The glass top is thick and is sturdy. But, the performance it really what we love about it. First, the safety features to prevent accidents are well designed. Everything that others have said about the speed of cooking and lack of wasted heat is true. It is also very easy to clean which is important to prevent buildup of difficult to remove debris. The only feature that could be improved is perhaps requiring a separate 2-step on-off switch for each element. As it stands, if one element of a zone is on, the others can be accidentally turned on by a simple touch. This is a minor issue. Overall, this is a great product and we highly recommend it.

This is an induction cooktop.

Very easy to use and clean.

Plus it heats the pan faster than any gas cooktop.

It takes special cookware, but many pots and pans are already induction ready as long as the bottom of the pan is magnetic.

The cooktop does get warm from the pan heating up, but the surface does not heat up cook.

If you are looking for a great cooktop this one is very good and at this price very comparable to other types of cooktops.

Minor complaints:, "1) It doesnt have 10 power levels, it has 5 power levels, and the pulses the power on and off at the lowest level to effectively reduce it further.  

The problem with this is that the power output for setting L (one step below 1) through 5 are all the same, which makes burning pancakes quite easy.

Review text:
"I am so happy with this induction cook top.

Ive only had a chance to use it 4 times, but it heats so much more quickly than my old coils and without the loss of heat to the room like when using gas.

And in Texas, thats a big deal when cooking in summer time.

I was not quite sure how happy I would be using induction and I did have to get an entire new set of pots and pans, but that investment is well worth the ease of using this item.

Review text: "Im giving 5 stars because it does what it claims, if I had paid what is typical for induction it would be 3.", To start - you get what you pay for. It's a cheap induction that functions really well. It's a bit smaller than typical electric cooktop untis so if you have granite and your switching to this be prepared to do some upgrades. What I did was install 1/4" flat stock steel plates on 2 sides of my existing opening and held them in place with 4400 psi epoxy., "After that the unit fit in perfectly and I caulked it in place to make sure it was snug and didnt move. They tell you to not caulk the unit as it needs to be removalable for service but I guess they dont know what a razor is and how easily it can be removed.", It takes 10 minutes to boil 1 gallon of water in a large stock pot. Each coil is exactly the same size regardless of what burner you use which is a bit frustrating. The only difference between the burners is amount of power that can be allocated to each., Cast iron is your friend in this instance and if you want to have the entire surface of a 12" cast iron pan hot you'll need to use boost for a few minutes then lower the temp to allow the heat to disperse to the entire pan., This is not normal.. I have a high end bertazzoni and each coil is designed for the specific burner. Once again you get what you pay for., "Im not sure if this is normal but our unit has a slight hot electronics smell when cooking. Maybe this is because its been installed less than 24 hours but its enough to be slightly alarming. I have a full open cabinet beneath and tons of ventilation so I know its nothing to do with that.", If this is your first induction range be prepared for a learning curve and a small investment of higher end cookware. The following work really well.., Cast iron, All-clad, Carbon steel, The following suck, Cheaply made metal alloys., "The following wont work", Aluminum, Glass cookware, "Youll save a bit on power but not how you think.. induction units use the same wattage as traditional electric ranges but it takes a lot less time to heat up. Which is another thing.. your cooking habits will change. No more start the pan and then start chopping up whatever your cooking. Now youll prep before turning the pan on.. hence the 20% of power savings most induction ranges claim.", Be ready for the noise. Most inductions (my bertazzoni excluded) make a hum/hiss noise when cooking. This is from the reaction of the metal cookware itself. Some higher end ranges have figured out how to minimize this but this range makes no attempt to. You can reduce it yourself by using cast iron.. the heavier the better..

This indicates that the heat response time of the electric-induction-range is slow.', 'sentiment': 'negative'}

Review text:
The easy work around for this is to use an induction plate between your induction cooktop and your induction pan to help even out the heating cycles.  

And no, I dont have thin pans, I have triple layer aluminum core pans.  

Because there is an effective work around I dont find this a major issue, but it is a definite drawback.  

All they needed to do was make the power pulse on and off at a faster rate rather than 4 seconds on, then 4 seconds off.

Review text: My unit arrived with the glass shattered in one corner. But I installed it temporarily before returning to see if I and my family would like it. Eventually, we decided not to get a replacement and to pay $1200 more for a big-name cooktop that has similar power and cooking performance, but a much easier to read display., The display and controls are the real deal-breaker. My counter is near a skylight and even without direct sunlight on it, I need to cup my hand over it to read it. In sunlight, I can't see anything at all. Can't even see if the cooktop is "on" or "off." If any grease has spattered on the surface, that also makes it hard to read. Given the unit's impressive power, this means we would incinerate a meal because we can't see the difference between cooking level 4 and level 9 or even "boost" (indicated by a 7-element "P")., "Installation is a breeze. Its light and you just set it in place and wire it up. It would be practical to use in an  outdoor kitchen if youve wired a 50A 2-phase plug outside. You could easily carry it in and out so as not to leave it exposed outdoors.", The elements are much smaller than you'd think, and this becomes apparent when using a pan that is the same size as the "burner" marked on the glass top. The actual diameter getting heated is about half what is marked, so you need to move the pan around if you want even searing. Similar issue with "bridging" pairs of burners., "The unit is a little noisy. The fan can be kind of like the fan on a laptop computer during heavy CPU use. One of my pots makes a noise like the Emergency Broadcast alert when heating on burst mode. For the most part, though, noise isnt so bad.", "Cooking speed is impressive! My 23 qt induction pressure canner comes up to full pressure in 330 seconds. Thats less than half what any other cooktop would do. Despite the uniformity issues, this thing really heats and sears better than any other stove Ive used short of a grill in a commercial kitchen."

Review text:
This is an induction cooktop.

Very easy to use and clean.

Plus it heats the pan faster than any gas cooktop.

It takes special cookware, but many pots and pans are already induction ready as long as the bottom of the pan is magnetic.

The cooktop does get warm from the pan heating up, but the surface does not heat up cook.

If you are looking for a great cooktop this one is very good and at this price very comparable to other types of cooktops.

I like the timer as it turns the cooktop off when the time is up.

Review text: I bought this unit specifically because of the wide-diameter heating coil, advertised as up to 10". With a cast iron pan, there's a distinct hot spot of 4"-5" diameter in the center, and the periphery is significantly cooler, even after allowing the pan to heat up for 20 minutes., The other disappointment is the inaccuracy of the temperature control. When I set the temp to 300, a laser thermometer registered 332. When I set it to 350, the thermometer registered 385. I guess this hot plate is a decent value if you recognize its limitations. Use the power control and ignore the temperature control. The 30-second max-power "boost" button is useful. I will use it for boiling and simmering large pots, which should be more forgiving of a smaller, hotter heating area, but I won't use it for pan cooking, like frying or sautéing, as the temperature differential from center to edge is too great. When I tried to cook several "silver dollar" pancakes at the same time, they ended up burned on one half but undercooked on the outer half. I had to finish the batch cooking them individually, which defeats the purpose of the wide-diameter heating coil that I thought I was buying.

Review text: "  When shopping for a portable induction cooktop, there is no shortage of options.  I chose the Hamilton Beach 34104 mainly for the benefit of a having a US-based company to call in case I had quality issues.  We purchased this induction cooktop for our first vacation during the pandemic, staying in a remote lodge and not wanting to be limited with our options for meals.  We set up it up in our room to reheat pre-made meals or to make breakfast burritos and hot sandwiches.  Upon initial use, the control was not quite intuitive (especially since we left the manual at home).  There are power settings ranging from 1-10 and temperature settings starting at 175deg F.  Like any induction cooktop, it takes a while to figure out the settings that suit the cooking scenario.  Its also important to note that the cookware needs to be ferrous, which you can check with the magnet.  Once we got the hang of the cooking settings we were pleased with the convenience of having cooking abilities on-the-go.  Also, the cooktop is easy to clean, with a totally flat glass surface."

Review text: "  Traditional hotplates simply cant compare to inductive hotplates for versatility and speed, but this hotplate takes it a step further by allowing you to cook via temperature ranges or specific temperatures with a clear read out.  And the added peace of mind knowing if you forget to turn it off, it wont be a hot surface waiting to be inadvertently touched by the unsuspecting.  Once the pan is removed the plate starts cooling off immediately and is safe to touch within a minute or two instead of 5-10.  Also, if you forge to shut it off, it still cools down.  These are the features that make inductive stove tops so popular today, and this just brings all that to a very convenient and portable size great for camping, a small apartment, dorm room, or if you just need an extra burner."

Review text: I needed an emergency cooktop while my kitchen stovetop was being repaired.  Since I have induction pans, preferred to stick with induction.  I researched, and this unit worked/ and heated just as well as my "powerful" installed kitchen stovetop.  Well, a little slower on boiling water, maybe a minute.....But great steady heat.  It has a "power" and "temperature" option of heating, I found for simmering, that "temperature" option was able to go to a lower temperature, where the 1st step in Power was still to hot., I have been very happy with this product, and now use it for out of doors grilling (I do take the unit in at night) It is light weight enough to carry around.

Review text:
"  Im impressed with the induction technology.

It heats the pan instantly and evenly, however my complaint with this model is if you pick the pan up it will turn off, completely, in 3 seconds.

Immediately the burner turns off as it should, but after 3 seconds the entire unit turns off.

So you have to press power, and turn it back up to the power level if you lift the pan to flip something.

Very annoying."

Review text:
I am in love with this induction cooktop.

First I have a glass top stove and I had no idea that I couldn’t use my castiron cookware.  

This has affected so many of my recipes.

This cooktop has let me enjoy my castiron cook ware, the heating is even.

I am in love with induction cooking as the heat covers the entire pan used.

Plus it was fun to be-able to take with it outside and use it there too!

It has been a wonderful addition to my cooking life.

"  Great cooktop!

Really efficient.

However, it doesnt work at all with my older Farberware pots.

They are stainless steel with an aluminum-clad bottom.

The old pots dont have a ferrous core, so induction cant occur.

Be sure a magnet will stick to the bottom of your existing pots before buying.

Otherwise, youll need to buy new pots as well."

Review text: This is a well made induction hearing element and I was anxious to give it a try as an extension to my existing burners on my stove., First, I had assumed that any metal pan would work, but I was wrong... The pan has to have some actual steel in it. It turns out, most of my cookware doesnt work. (Aluminum and some stainless wont work - cast iron and some stainless will). I do have 2 stainless pans that work. You can test your cookware with a refrigerator magnet. (It even comes with a magnet for this purpose). If the magnet sticks, the pan will work., So, to see how it would compare, I put 8 cups of room temperature (72 deg F) water in a pan. It took 8 minutes, 21 seconds to get a full boil. The odd thing was that while it was fully boiling, the temperature only showed 201 degrees with my thermometer. As soon as I turned it off, the boiling immediately stopped. That makes me believe that at least some of the boiling action was due to the induction process itself, rather than actually being at temperature., "For comparison, I did the same thing on my electric stoves burner. It took right at 9 minutes to come to a full boil (and it was actually at temperature over 212 deg). So the induction heat was really about the same - at least not enough difference to make a difference in my unscientific study.", "Its still a well made, properly functioning device and as long as youre aware of the limitations of induction coil heating elements, I think this one is definitely recommendable."

Review text: I am thinking about getting a full size inductive cooktop for a kitchen remodel.  I thought trying this portable unit to get a feel for that first was a good idea.  Plus I can use this version for camping outdoor cooking etc.  The manual that comes with didn’t tell you how to cook with it.  Eg what temperatures for what items.  The manual is pertaining to stove operation.  That said, I’ve been experimenting.  It’s much more responsive than regular electric cooktop stoves and similar to gas where you can adjust heat level quickly.  I love the cool to the touch safety feature.  It’s easy to clean.  It’s larger than I thought.  It had a quick button for plain boiling.  It did take longer for water to boil than I expected.  I will say all in all I am ready to take the plunge in a full size built in inductive cooktop.

Review text: I\ve had this product for about a month and have used it every day. I have only used one side and wish I bought the single burner because it\s actually quite big. I love the easy wipe down and the glass top has stayed like new. It heats up magnetic pans in seconds and the higher heat levels are great for boiling and reducing. Using a light stainless steel pan I can change temperatures instantly. The only thing bad is that the element heating circle is about 6 inches per side which is small considering the size of the top. In a 12" skillet there can be hot spots. Using a thicker pan helps but changing temps is slower. Overall I am pleased, but this is not a $1200 stove top, it\s a hot plate. This is not 220 or a 440 volt unit with full size heating elements, but it still works fine with common sense.

Review text: Comparison tested this morning: Drag race between a cast iron skillet and "induction ready" aluminum. Both eight inches in diameter, both one inch deep water, both on the left side, both set on maximum power, "boil". First the cast iron came to a violent rolling boil in around three and a half minutes. Then the "induction ready" aluminum that came to a very minimal boil in around eleven minutes, no complete rolling boil after eighteen minutes. Although a five quart stew simmered very nicely, with almost instant temperature control, one touch and boiling stops, another touch and boiling resumes. When the timer expires warm automatically begins. Temperature can be reduced down to 100 degrees in 20 degree steps., Note that I also tried another brand of "induction ready" cookware with very similar results., I am good with the product. It can be a double slow cooker if you like. An "induction ready" skillet does an excellent job with bacon and eggs on this cooktop and as quickly as I could want.

Review text: I bought this item as a "used" unit due to slightly damaged packaging at more than $50 off the asking price 19 months ago and it\s still going strong. I simply couldn\t be happier!, I already had a single Duxtop burner for a while, which I really liked and wanted to upgrade to two induction burners. After reading the information before buying about the limitations of using this two-burner unit with the maximum allotted 1800 amps split between the burners, I was a little bit worried if there would be enough heat. I was also worried that using just one of the dual burners on this unit might be less powerful than my old single-burner Duxtop. No worries, I was wrong!, I frequently use both burners on this Duxtop LCD Portable Double Induction Cooktop with no problems. My cooking habits are usually gentle sautéing, braising, or simmering, which require no more than medium heat (level 5) with good induction cookware. Of course I do like to heat above medium (up to level 10) once in a while for searing or a quick boil, but I never have to do that on two burners at a time, so no problems there., "Some reviewers have complained about the fan noise, which doesnt bother me after using the old single-burner Duxtop. The sound of the range stove hood in my kitchen is louder and drowns out the sound of the Duxtop fans anyway.", "A few reviewers were surprised about the limitations of cookware they could use on this Duxtop or any other induction cooker. It is a different way of cooking and the ususal non-magnetic aluminum pots/pans dont work at all. Old-timey cast iron, or cast-iron enamelware is best, but just make sure to see if cookware is induction compatible before you buy it online. If you buy pots and pans in person at a store, take a refrigerator magnet with you. If the magnet sticks well to the pan you want to buy, its induction-ready! Do the magnet test with existing cookware at home, too, to see what already works.", The glasstop unit is easy to clean and I like the Duxtop better than my gas burners!

Review text:
I love it.  

I like the fact that it heats up so quickly, is easy to adjust up and down, has a timer so I can walk away if necessary without worrying that the dish will burn and is easy to clean.  

I use induction cooktop mats under my pans to protect the top from scratching and a silicone mat over the whole thing when I'm not using it, to keep it clean and unscratched, which gives me a great extra surface when I'm using the microwave.  

The only "con" is that the fan is loud.

Review text: Just going to make two points here, since most other reviews have covered everything else., 1) Many people assume the temperature settings on this (and other) induction cook tops refers to the temperature of the contents of your pot, for instance, if you set the temp to 180 people think the contents of the pot will be 180 degrees. That is not how these work. The temperature setting is referencing the temperature the induction coil will produce. It is the equivalent to setting your gas stove flame to low, medium or high. It does not control the temperature of your pot, it just determines how much heat is applied to the pot. This will determine how quickly your pot will reach maximum temperature. This is not a thermostatic device, it merely sets the temp of the coil. The higher the temperature setting the faster your pot will get hot. Simple as that. If you want to control the cooking temperature I would suggest you use a sous vide pot, with which you can control the temperature of the cooking water to within 1 degree., "2) People seem to think the cooking plate surface should not be hot because there is no flame. It is accurate that the cooking surface will not get hot when turned on - if the device is turned on and there is no pot or pan on the surface the cooking surface will stay cool. However, once you boil your water or cook your sauce, dont forget you have a ten pound pot filled with food sitting on the cooking surface, and the pot or pan is likely over 200 degrees. So if you put a hot pot on ANY surface, the hot pot will make that surface hot, too. People in other reviews complained they burned their fingers because they put their hands on the cooking surface after removing a boiling pot assuming the cooking surface would still be cool. How a surface would stay cool with a boiling pot of water on it beats me, but these people deserve the Darwin award for not thinking this through. The cooking surface DOES get hot, but from the hot pot, not from the cooking elements.", Good luck out there.

That is not how these work. The temperature setting is referencing the temperature the induction coil will produce.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user has mentioned that people assume the temperature settings on this induction cook tops refers to the temperature of the contents of your pot, but that is not how these work. The temperature setting is referencing the temperature the induction coil will produce.', 'sentiment': 'negative'}

Review text:
I primarily purchased this cooktop to use out on my deck for pan searing, browning meats, and making wok stir fry dishes.

My vent hood does not vent outside, so it keeps the cooking odors out of the house.

Temperature control is great.

The child lock and timer safety features are very much appreciated.

Excellent value for price.

Highly recommend.

Review text:
We use this cooktop in our camper van and it works great.

It is compact for easy storage and heats food up real fast.

It is even faster than our gas stove at home.

I run regular checks on its energy consumption and found it to be very energy efficient.

This is important since we run it through our lithium batteries when we camp in the wild.

Highly recommended.

Other than that, it is a great cook-top item.

The pan heats up almost immediately.

Review text: "We ordered this induction cooktop to replace an older electric burner unit.  Since we knew nothing about induction technology and the unknown Thermomate manufacturer was in China and we purchased online, we entered into the purchase with a gamblers mindset.  If anything about the project went south, we would just call it a gambling loss and  replace it with another electric cooktop purchased locally and chalk the whole thing up to experience.", After an unexplained 2 day shipping delay, the new Thermomate unit arrived in perfect condition.  As soon as Amazon noticed there was a delay in shipping they sent a note saying that if it did not arrive by a certain date they would replace or refund my money.  I unwired the old unit, removed it and dropped the new unit in place.  It took just minutes to hook up the wires and turn the unit on.  Meanwhile my wife was reading the owners manual, trying to figure out how to operate her new cooktop.  With just a little practice she was up and running.  Her statement is, ""I've never had such precision in cooking.  The temperature control is perfect. I'm thrilled with your product."  My statement is, "I'm thrilled she's happy.  She does the cooking and she's good at it.", Yesterday we received a note from Thermomate that we should contact them if we encountered any problems with the unit.  That was reassuring and eliminated the gambling mindset., Sincerely,, Don Fink

Review text: I have been thinking about switching to induction for a while. When this was featured on Prime Day, I had to try it and so far I’m very impressed. Installation was a bit challenging, not the stoves fault, so it took a couple of hours when it should have been 30 minutes. Turned it on and was instantly impressed. It looks fantastic, is extremely easy to operate, and is fast to heat.  There are several safety features built it that keep from accidentally turning on.  Highly recommend this device as it seems very well made. This should also save on electricity.  I did purchase the extended warranty but don’t think that I will need it.

Review text: "We purchased a name-brand unit at our old home several years ago and used it for 5 years before selling the home.  We have the correct pots and pans for the induction oven and have the experience of using it.  We just purchased a home and needed an induction cooktop to replace the 60s unit that was here.  The pandemic has made buying appliances difficult and I had to settle on this.  The unit is easy to install and wire.  The unit will heat for approximately 5 seconds and then cycle off for 5 over and over.  My other unit did not do this..it heated continuously.  If you are cooking for any length of time the unit will not lower the heat or turn off.  We had to reset the breaker at least twice a week to get the cooktop to turn off.  The cooktop is very sensitive to water and will turn off with just a little bit.  I sent this unit back and will never purchase this brand again.  I understand this unit is cheap compared to the name brand, but you get what you pay for."

"Ive had every kind of stove, and thought I was in love with gas.

Thought is the key word.

This cooktop is actually faster, and able to keep a perfect temperature without fluctuating.

Simple, intuitive controls, easy to clean and a joy to use.

The one thing you have to be aware of is that it needs pans that work on an induction cooktop (magnetic).

It allowed me to get rid of most of our 20+ year collections of pans, buy one GOOD set and save storage space as well.

Ill never go back to gas.

Review text: "  I bought this induction hob for the lockdown period. Only reason I didnt send it back was because I needed to isolate, and so I couldnt be without something to cook on.", "The product is frankly dangerous;'xa0Ive seen the sellers stock replies where they say there is a +-20 degree variance on the temperature settings –'xa0rubbish!", I put it on 60 degrees to start with, because at this setting it goes straight to well over 100 degrees in practice. Hot contents start to spit out of the pan; you could easy burn yourself or a small child if you had one nearby., After a couple of minutes, it will settle at approximately the set temperature. Then you notch it up to 90, and it boils violently again, until it settles at 90. Then you go 120, and after a couple of minutes it seems to settle at less than 100., "The temperatures are not as expected and not consistent. Further, there is no 100 degree setting; it is impossible to simmer using this hob, which is the main reason I state Not Designed By A Cook. This is massive oversight in a cooking device. Best I could do was put the pan off to the side of the ring, so that one side gets really hot and you get an overall simmer of sorts; but you get the side of the pan getting so hot it goes red, and a load of burnt food on that side.", Most cooking is going to be done at under to just over 100 degrees, and most of that around 100; well most of mine is. Occasionally you want higher, e.g. searing meat and making flatbreads etc.., Considering this, the steps of 60, 90, 120, 140, 160, 180, 200, 220, 240 are poorly thought-out; there needs to be smaller increments at the lower end of the scale than at the higher end, since this is where you really need your fine control., "Another issue is that the heat does not come through; the base of the pan gets hot, but its not like gas or regular electric rings where the heat rises up through the food. So you get uneven cooking. No frittatas on this hob... the egg is liquid at the top whilst cooked and burned at the bottom.", Positive points: It heats up liquids fast. It reheats soups and curries fast. Cooks meats ok (though again 120 is often too high). Cooks flatbreads well., "In summary, I use it for what I can use it for. Couldnt cook my curries on this though, so I bought a slow cooker.", "Final point: Its pretty noisy and I cant listen to it for long periods; another Im reason Im glad for the slow cooker.", "Closing thought: I dont know whos writing these 5* reviews."

Review text: "The unit itself appears to be well made, but the controls are bizarre. You cant do anything until you select watts or temperature and the second you press this button it begins cooking at the default setting. If you want a low setting and you want to see it in degrees, you press the button wich starts cooking and displaying watts, press again to get temp, then press the down button several times to reduce the temparature to where you want it.", If you press the watts/temp button during cooking it immediately returns to the default setting - why?, Why does the watts setting even exist? Who knows how many watts to cook at?, "The temperatures go up in 20 degrees (celcius) starting at 60. If you want to simmer it is virtually impossible. At 100 degrees you have an agressive boil and at 80 degrees you are barely warming the food. The actual temperature options are different to those shown in one of the images, which shows a 90 degree option that doesnt exist. The image also shows simmer as being at the top end of the scale (about 220 degrees, I think) and that cant be right, can it?", For the £45 I paid for it and for the simple purpose I have for it, the unit provides value for money, but you need to be aware of the controls and be sure this will suit your needs., If there were another unit with better temperature controls then I would return it, but the other devices are no better and mostly worse.

Review text: "Ive had this 1 week.  I have a gas stove but prefer the sspeed and efficiency of induction.  This is my 3rd induction top in maybe 6 years (melted cord on one and dropped hammer on 2nd).  This is over and above the quietest.  When I first turned it on I thought the fan hadnt come on.  The heating element seems to be a little wider than the other two making less of a hot spot in the center of the pan.  Controls are easy to use.  The only thing I need to get used to is the heating option is either in degrees or wattage.  My last too induction cookers had a number 1, 1.5, 2, 5, 8, etc.  Now I have to figure out where the sweet spot is as far as wattage setting.  It took 3 minutes to boil a tea kettle full of cold tap water at the highest wattage.  So far its all thumbs up."

Review text:
I cook meat on this at 120 C but the plate heats up nicely to begin with, the meat starts sizzling and then after 2  minutes it cools down and after 2 or so more minutes it heats up again and then cools down.

Really hard to cook when the temperature is like a rollercoaster.

Even worse if you cook at 140 or above you end up with burnt food.

Really unhappy with this purchase.

Review text: "  I bought this induction hob for the lockdown period. Only reason I didnt send it back was because I needed to isolate, and so I couldnt be without something to cook on.", "The product is frankly dangerous;'xa0Ive seen the sellers stock replies where they say there is a +-20 degree variance on the temperature settings –'xa0rubbish!", I put it on 60 degrees to start with, because at this setting it goes straight to well over 100 degrees in practice. Hot contents start to spit out of the pan; you could easy burn yourself or a small child if you had one nearby., After a couple of minutes, it will settle at approximately the set temperature. Then you notch it up to 90, and it boils violently again, until it settles at 90. Then you go 120, and after a couple of minutes it seems to settle at less than 100., "The temperatures are not as expected and not consistent. Further, there is no 100 degree setting; it is impossible to simmer using this hob, which is the main reason I state Not Designed By A Cook. This is massive oversight in a cooking device. Best I could do was put the pan off to the side of the ring, so that one side gets really hot and you get an overall simmer of sorts; but you get the side of the pan getting so hot it goes red, and a load of burnt food on that side.", Most cooking is going to be done at under to just over 100 degrees, and most of that around 100; well most of mine is. Occasionally you want higher, e.g. searing meat and making flatbreads etc.., Considering this, the steps of 60, 90, 120, 140, 160, 180, 200, 220, 240 are poorly thought-out; there needs to be smaller increments at the lower end of the scale than at the higher end, since this is where you really need your fine control., "Another issue is that the heat does not come through; the base of the pan gets hot, but its not like gas or regular electric rings where the heat rises up through the food. So you get uneven cooking. No frittatas on this hob... the egg is liquid at the top whilst cooked and burned at the bottom.", Positive points: It heats up liquids fast. It reheats soups and curries fast. Cooks meats ok (though again 120 is often too high). Cooks flatbreads well., "In summary, I use it for what I can use it for. Couldnt cook my curries on this though, so I bought a slow cooker.", "Final point: Its pretty noisy and I cant listen to it for long periods; another Im reason Im glad for the slow cooker.", "Closing thought: I dont know whos writing these 5* reviews."

This works fantastically, it is designed for induction cooking so make sure your pans are compatible.

If they arent then the hob will not heat up.

A good test if you are unsure is to see if they are magnetic.

The hob itself is large with a slim profile, it easily fits in to kitchen cupboards and stores away nicely.

The controls are touch sensitive and its very easy to master them.

The temperature can be set,the time limit and it can be locked.

Review text:
First time using induction and not disappointed.  

Was skeptical on buying this brand vs big name brands but so far it’s been working well.  

No issues with exception you have to have pans that are compatible with induction.  

It is a little noisy once you turn on but once I add food to the pan I don’t even notice.  

For the price I think it’s worth giving it a try.

Review text: First time owning a conduction cooktop so not certain how they shoudl function.  This one looks good and was easy to install (we did have it professionally installed).  Took a bit to figure out how to turn it on; the cooktop locks and then you have to unlock specific burner and then turn on.  I guess reading the directions would help. Review text: 'xa0Anyone who doesn’t know anything about induction need to explore a little bit to know about how this works. I’ve heard about it a lot but never actually tried one until now. This one is my first induction cooker. On first use when it boiled water within 1 minutes I was just shocked how efficient this technology is., Coming to product itself I was impressed how well this product was packaged. I have found many seller compromising packaging just to lower some weight making actual product vulnerable to breakage. This one is inside two boxes directly from manufacturer. Inside it is well wrapped in safety cases and plastics. There was not a single scratch or any complain on the aesthetic view. Kudos to packaging., The provided manual is all I needed to get started. It was actually easy. Just plugin and have a pan/dish to cooking area and press power button and press watt/temp button which will start it. We have to be careful with induction technology that we shouldn’t keep empty pan on cooking area for long time without any content on it . If there is no pan on cooking area then it won’t turn on at all. It will give a single indicating it can’t start. Controller is touch sensitive and it have lock button to prevent accidental touched to controller. I can control the power of each burner individually. The maximum wattage of this unit it 1800 Watt. If I use only one burner I can go upto 1800 watt in single one. With two burner on I have it one at 800 and other at 1000. The controller is really responsive. As soon as I press the button I can see instant effect on my food. May be this is more of induction rather than product ifself. The LED display is clear and informative., For cleaning it is so much easy. Top part is glass I think which is usual case for all induction cooker and is so for this one as well. I press the lock button and do the cleaning with wet towels and it works perfectly. Overall impressed with this product and the efficiency of induction technology.

Review text: 'xa0Anyone who doesn’t know anything about induction need to explore a little bit to know about how this works. I’ve heard about it a lot but never actually tried one until now. This one is my first induction cooker. On first use when it boiled water within 1 minutes I was just shocked how efficient this technology is., Coming to product itself I was impressed how well this product was packaged. I have found many seller compromising packaging just to lower some weight making actual product vulnerable to breakage. This one is inside two boxes directly from manufacturer. Inside it is well wrapped in safety cases and plastics. There was not a single scratch or any complain on the aesthetic view. Kudos to packaging., The provided manual is all I needed to get started. It was actually easy. Just plugin and have a pan/dish to cooking area and press power button and press watt/temp button which will start it. We have to be careful with induction technology that we shouldn’t keep empty pan on cooking area for long time without any content on it . If there is no pan on cooking area then it won’t turn on at all. It will give a single indicating it can’t start. Controller is touch sensitive and it have lock button to prevent accidental touched to controller. I can control the power of each burner individually. The maximum wattage of this unit it 1800 Watt. If I use only one burner I can go upto 1800 watt in single one. With two burner on I have it one at 800 and other at 1000. The controller is really responsive. As soon as I press the button I can see instant effect on my food. May be this is more of induction rather than product ifself. The LED display is clear and informative., For cleaning it is so much easy. Top part is glass I think which is usual case for all induction cooker and is so for this one as well. I press the lock button and do the cleaning with wet towels and it works perfectly. Overall impressed with this product and the efficiency of induction technology.

Review text: 'xa0Anyone who doesn’t know anything about induction need to explore a little bit to know about how this works. I’ve heard about it a lot but never actually tried one until now. This one is my first induction cooker. On first use when it boiled water within 1 minutes I was just shocked how efficient this technology is., Coming to product itself I was impressed how well this product was packaged. I have found many seller compromising packaging just to lower some weight making actual product vulnerable to breakage. This one is inside two boxes directly from manufacturer. Inside it is well wrapped in safety cases and plastics. There was not a single scratch or any complain on the aesthetic view. Kudos to packaging., The provided manual is all I needed to get started. It was actually easy. Just plugin and have a pan/dish to cooking area and press power button and press watt/temp button which will start it. We have to be careful with induction technology that we shouldn’t keep empty pan on cooking area for long time without any content on it . If there is no pan on cooking area then it won’t turn on at all. It will give a single indicating it can’t start. Controller is touch sensitive and it have lock button to prevent accidental touched to controller. I can control the power of each burner individually. The maximum wattage of this unit it 1800 Watt. If I use only one burner I can go upto 1800 watt in single one. With two burner on I have it one at 800 and other at 1000. The controller is really responsive. As soon as I press the button I can see instant effect on my food. May be this is more of induction rather than product ifself. The LED display is clear and informative., For cleaning it is so much easy. Top part is glass I think which is usual case for all induction cooker and is so for this one as well. I press the lock button and do the cleaning with wet towels and it works perfectly. Overall impressed with this product and the efficiency of induction technology.

Review text:
"Easy to clean and operate.

This was my first induction cooktop, so I didnt really know what I was looking for.

The problem I have had is that the temperature increments are too large, like a 30+ degree difference.

Food can be frying too much because the pan is too hot, turn it down one step

and it will barely be sizzling.

The same with boiling/simmering.

Get something to a rolling boil, turn it down one step

and then it wont even be at a simmer.

Review text: I bought this because my friend recommended to me. I’ve bought for so long and never used it. Then I decided to eat Hot Pot since it was getting cold.
